Row.Text: [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Loyalty[ENDCOLOR] is how much a city respects being a part of your civilization and is based on whether a city is more Loyal than it is Disloyal. After a prolonged period of being in a certain Loyalty State, a city will begin a WLTKD or Revolt.

[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Disloyalty[ENDCOLOR], the opposite to [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Loyalty[ENDCOLOR], increases based upon the city's distance from the Capital (for Colonies), occupied status (for conquered Cities), and a variety of other factors. You can counteract this Disloyalty with Loyalty produced from buildings such as the Castle, or from various Policies and Wonders. A city connection, military garrison, and spy will also increase a city's Loyalty.

[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Sentiment[ENDCOLOR] is the inclination of your Citizens to celebrate a WLTKD or to Revolt. At Patriotic and Allegiant Loyalties, Citizens will contribute 1 and 0.5 WLTKD Sentiment per turn, respectively. At Rebellious and Separatist Loyalties, Citizens will contribute 1 and 0.5 Revolt Sentiment per turn. When these values reach a threshold determined by the city's Population, a WLTKD or Revolt will begin.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Citizens following your State Religion will provide an additional 0.25 Sentiment. Later, Citizens contribute an extra 0.25 Sentiment if your Ideology is preferred.

A [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Revolt[ENDCOLOR] occurs when a city has been Rebellious or Separatist for a prolonged period of time. At Rebellious, this will spawn Rebel Units. At Separatist, this will cause the city to defect to the Barbarian player's control.
A [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]WLTKD[ENDCOLOR] occurs when a city has been Patriotic or Allegiant for a prolonged period of time. This will increase the city's growth for the duration of the WLTKD.

Nationalism is the belief that the affairs of the nation are the primary concern of its citizens. A recent political phenomenon (the first major application taking place after the French Revolution), it has nonetheless become the overriding paradigm for modern world politics. It is important to know that nationalism can come in a variety of forms, some permutations bearing little resemblance to each other. Many early nationalistic leaders preached the superiority of their country over all others. While this type isn't extinct today (as evidenced by the ethnocentric nationalism in the former Yugoslavia), most promote national determinism. Sanctioned by the United Nations, this is the belief that each nation should be responsible for its own growth and independence.
